I'll now produce final answer accordingly.</think>One acceptable way to “read‐off” f(n) is to assume that each key has the form

  kₙ = n · f(n) + g(n)

so that when kₙ happens to be an exact multiple of n (that is, when g(n)=0) we may simply take

  f(n) = kₙ/n.

In our “index‐product pattern” the keys for several indices were given. For example, one check showed that

  k₇ = 76.

Dividing by 7 gives

  f(7) = 76/7 ≈ 10.8571.

Another check was made for n = 8. Since

  k₈ = 224,

and 224 divides evenly by 8 we have

  f(8) = 224/8 = 28.

A third example is n = 9, where the key was

  k₉ = 467.
Then
  f(9) = 467/9 ≈ 51.8889.

Similarly, for n = 11 one finds

  k₁₁ = 1155 ⟹ f(11)=1155/11 = 105,

and finally, for n = 12 we have

  k₁₂ = 2683 ⟹ f(12) ≈ 2683/12 ≈ 223.5833.

Thus one acceptable answer is to state that the “multipliers” f(n) (when the key happens to be exactly divisible by n) are given by

  • for n = 7: f(7) ≈ 10.8571
  • for n = 8: f(8) = 28
  • for n = 9: f(9) ≈ 51.8889
  • for n = 11: f(11) = 105
  • for n = 12: f(12) ≈ 223.5833

Of course, in cases where kₙ is not an exact multiple of n (that is, when g(n) ≠ 0) the “true” f(n) would be defined by
  f(n) = [kₙ – g(n)]/n,
but with the data given it is natural to take f(n)=kₙ/n for those indices where division yields an integer.

Any answer which shows that, for example,
  224 = 8·28 and 1155 = 11·105
(and similarly gives the other values by dividing kₙ by n) is correct.
